review.title: Autoencoder-Driven Weather Clustering for Source Estimation during Nuclear Events
review.abstract: Emergency response applications for nuclear or radiological events can be significantly improved via deep feature learning due to the hidden complexity of the data and models involved. In this paper we present a novel methodology for rapid source estimation during radiological releases based on deep feature extraction and weather clustering. Atmospheric dispersions are then calculated based on identified predominant weather patterns and are matched against simulated incidents indicated by radiation readings on the ground. We evaluate the accuracy of our methods over multiple years of weather reanalysis data in the European region. We juxtapose these results with deep classification convolution networks and discuss advantages and disadvantages.

metadata.title: Autoencoder-Driven Weather Clustering for Source Estimation during Nuclear Events

sections.text: In this paper, we present a new method for rapid source estimation during radiological releases, based on the extraction of deep features and weather clustering. Atmospheric dispersions are then calculated on the basis of identified dominant weather patterns and compared with simulated events indicated by radiation measurements on the ground. We evaluate the accuracy of our methods using multi-year weather re-analysis data in the European region. We contrast these results with deep classification folding networks and discuss pros and cons.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: This study combines algorithms and methods from a number of disciplines, namely machine learning, weather circulation clusters, atmospheric dispersion and weather models. In this section, we give an overview of relevant work.

sections.heading: 2.1 Discovering Weather Patterns
sections.text: In recent decades, there have been several studies that attempted to discover weather patterns through unattended hierarchical and iterative clustering [14], as part of synoptic climatology [29]. Many of these studies have attempted to create statistically robust representations based on the calculation of major components in what this body of literature denotes, S and T modes. S mode refers to the typical application of major component analysis (PCA) per weather sample, which is used for the reduction of features, while T mode refers to the application of PCA per netpoint. (In our review, in Section 4, we refer to the T mode also as PCAT to indicate cases where PCA is applied to the "transposed" form of data samples.) Indicative, Huth [13] summarizes and compares the correlation, sum-of squares, agglomerative hierarchical, PCA means, and hierarchical agglomerative agglomeratives.

sections.heading: 2.2 Autoencoders for Feature Reduction
sections.text: An autoencoder [16, 2, 8] is an unattended, forward-facing neural network designed to approximate the identity function, i.e. one that attempts to learn a function h (x) = x (x) x, where x and x (each denote the input and output vectors). After training, applications typically ignore the output of autoencoders instead of using the activation values of the hidden layers. In the case of a simple, single-layer autoencoder, the hidden activations are equivalent to PCA [4]. In its simplest form, if there is a single hidden layer and the number of hidden units corresponds to the number of inputs, the autoencoder is too successful in replicating the input, resulting in revision. Various methods have been suggested to avoid overload, e.g. by having fewer hidden than input units.

sections.heading: 3 Methodology and Rationale
sections.text: Our methodology comprises two main steps: (1) the derivation of weather patterns to be used to drive reference cloud dispersion patterns, and (2) the subsequent estimate of the release origin. An overview of our methodology is shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 3.1 Weather Re-analysis Data and Features
sections.text: To discover weather patterns, we use weather analysis data, which is network data derived from optimal combinations of Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) and observations, making it the best available description of past atmospheric conditions. Weather re-analysis data covers a sufficiently large period (40 years) and is of sufficient spatial (less than 1 hour) and temporal (up to 6 hours) resolution across the region of interest, i.e. the European continent. This data set is freely available as part of the ERA Interim Project [6] and is provided by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecast (ECMWF). For this study, we used interim global ERA data spanning 11 years (1986-1993 and 1996-1998) with a 6-hour resolution provided by NCAR in format 3.

sections.heading: 3.2 Dispersion and Inverse Models
sections.text: Atmospheric dispersion models are calculation codes that simulate the processes of transport and diffusion of air pollutants, as well as other physical processes that occur during dispersion, such as deposition on the ground and transformations (chemical reactions, radioactive decay, etc.). Dispersion model calculations are based on meteorological data as calculated by the WRF, above. Dispersion models can work "in advance" (prognostically) if the pollutant emission types and associated emission quantities (known as time functions) are known. They can also be used in "reverse" calculations, where, in combination with available measured pollutant concentrations, unknown pollutant emission types and emission rates are estimated. There are several types of atmospheric dispersion models. In this work, which include dispersions in long spatial ranges that refer to complex topography and high meteorological variability, we call the atmospheric dispersion models.

sections.heading: 3.4 Source Estimation
sections.text: To estimate the origin of the release, we follow a two-step matching process. After an event has occurred, we first identify the weather pattern that best represents the current weather. Multiple similarity (or distance) metrics can be used for this calculation. If we treat this comparison as an additional k-mean assignment step, we select the cluster that minimizes the Euclidean distance between the observed weather vector w and the center of the cluster in question. Based on our choice of a representative weather pattern, we then consider the dispersions previously calculated for our group of fixed release origin candidates. The probability that a location is the source of the release can be calculated by comparing the release distributions of the cluster-based dispersions with hypothetical detection measurements. A hypothetical event is determined by a sequence of measurements at specific locations that we compare with the probability of the release origin.

sections.heading: 4.1 Origin Estimation as a Classification Task
sections.text: In addition to this study, we experimented with deep Convolutionary Networks [16] that treated the estimate of release origin as a classification problem. As this was intended as a preliminary study, we used the data produced as an evaluation data set for the cluster-based approach. We increased our weather and dispersion samples tenfold, and the weather data was increased by introducing random noises for 20 nuclear facilities in Europe and for 3-day periods, resulting in a tenfold increase in weather and dispersion samples.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a novel cluster-based approach based on machine learning for rapid estimation of the origin of nuclear events. Our approach is inspired by image processing, deep learning and data mining, which extends useful techniques to weather and atmospheric dispersion data. Inspired by the need to develop ML-capable reusable data products to enable the creation of complex applications, we discussed the derivation of usable weather patterns by clustering. We used deep autoencoders to derive robust latent properties for the application of clusters. By thoroughly evaluating our application, we provide evidence of effectiveness and usefulness in the field of nuclear emergency response and in adjacent areas, using complex physical models and large geospatial data.
